He did finally touch down safely,

It goes without saying that Larry, upon touchdown, was arrested.

and a few crack reporters witnessed his arrest.
One of those reporters asked why he'd done it.
Larry's response?
"A man can't just sit around."

recText: One Saturday at eleven-thirty

recText: Then I see her leaving the house heading toward town

origText: I quickly follow.
Susie has turned the corner and is walking down the block towards the traffic light.
She passes the corner store and walks behind the small strip mall,
I start thinking that I know where she is going.
recText: Suddenly I think I know where Susie is going.

origText: Mr. Johnston’s Fresh Fish Market is in a small, white building at the back of the strip mall.
I see that Susie has joined several of her cat colleagues.
recText: I watch as Susie approaches this building, followed by several of her cat colleagues.

origText: Mr. Johnston comes out of the back door, carrying several black trash bags.
recText: The owner of the fish market walks outside holding several trash bags in hand.

origText: He piles them into the dumpster, and then pulls out a small, clear plastic bag full of fish heads.
He scatters these on the ground and watches the cats pounce on them.
recText: He looks at the cats, and scatters a bags worth of fish-heads on the ground in front of them

origText: He spies me lurking by the corner of the strip mall.
“Hi Ryan,” he calls in his thick Brooklyn accent.
recText: The owner greets me in his thick Brooklyn accent,

origText: “So this is where Susie comes at noon,” I say, walking towards him.
recText: “So this is where Susie goes every day at noon!”

origText: Mr. Johnston laughs.
“Yep.  All the cats come to visit me at noon.
They used to tear up my garbage,
so now I just put the fish heads on the ground for them.
Is that your cat?”
recText: “which one of these is yours, Ryan?”

origText: “Yes, that’s my Susie,” I say.

I wait until Susie finishes her fish head,
and we walk home together.
